qas.question: What was the name of the anonymously published science book?

answers.text: Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation

qas.question: What kind of progression did Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation propose?
Who wrote Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation?
What was the evidence in Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation used to support?

answers.text: that living things had progressed from the simple to the more complex over time.

qas.question: Which scientist was in favor of Lamarckism in the 1850s?

context: In November 1844, the anonymously published popular science book <a0_0>Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation<a0_0/>, written by Scottish journalist <a2_0>Robert Chambers<a2_0/>, widened public interest in the concept of transmutation of species. Vestiges used evidence from the fossil record and embryology to support the claim <a3_0>that living things had progressed from the simple to the more complex over time.<a3_0/> But it proposed <a1_0>a linear progression<a1_0/> rather than the branching common descent theory behind Darwin's work in progress, and it ignored adaptation. Darwin read it soon after publication, and scorned its amateurish geology and zoology, but he carefully reviewed his own arguments after leading scientists, including Adam Sedgwick, attacked its morality and scientific errors. Vestiges had significant influence on public opinion, and the intense debate helped to pave the way for the acceptance of the more scientifically sophisticated Origin by moving evolutionary speculation into the mainstream. While few naturalists were willing to consider transmutation, <a4_0>Herbert Spencer<a4_0/> became an active proponent of Lamarckism and progressive development in the 1850s.
